title: What makes a movie Hit or Flop? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hit or Flop are just another terms for the financial success of a film e.g. Profit or Loss. In terms of Indian films to determine the profit or loss is little complicate.There are lots of points to consider before giving a theatrical verdict to a film.  Films are made by producers (in financial terms). Sometimes producers themselves are the distributors of the film (Like Yashraj, Dharma Reliance, Eros etc.) Sometimes Producers sell the film to the distributors (Individual Producers like Bonny Kapoor, Vashu Bhagnani etc. prefers this) and secure their profit. In the second case, The film is always a hit for the producers as they have already earned from the film. Still theatrical verdict matters, because it adds credits or discredits to their future projects.Now, the distributors spend a good amount of money on the marketing and promotion of the film. Now days, Promotion is one of the key factors to make a film hit or flop. Generally, distributors spend 10-20 Cr. on the promotions. Now the amount distributors paid to the producers and promotion amount, Sum of the both is the new cost of the film. Distributors sell various rights (Like satellite rights, Music right etc.) and try to secure as much amount as they can. Distributors sell the film to sub-distributors of various film territories. Presently, presently territories for distribution of Hindi films are divided into eleven territories and one oversees territory. Sub-distributors sell the film to the theater owners. Whatever film earns by selling the tickets is known as Gross income. Whatever theater earns, first they pay 20% Entertainment tax to government. (Single screens as well as Multiplexes) After paying Entertainment Tax, Theater owners share the earnings with distributors. It depends on the nature of theater. In most of the cases, it is like25:75 (Single Screen theater owner : Distributor) (Varies 20:80 or 30:70) and Multiplex owner : Distributor Week 1 - 50:50Week 2 - 60:40Week 3 - 70:30Later - same as week 3(Subject to terms of agreement) 8. Now,whatever amount distributors get is known as Net income. If the Net income(selling of tickets and rights) is more than the cost (Amount paid to the producer + Promotions) film will be declare as hit otherwise film will be a flop. The difference of the amount between Cost and Net income will define the terms -  Flop,Super-flop, Hit, Super-hit, and Blockbuster etc.

Money. The collections of movie decide whether it is a hit or flop.  A movie should make profit for producers and distributors to consider it a hit.  Take an example. Suppose a movie named X is made at a cost of 20 crores. This means the producer invested his 20 crores in the movie. Nowadays, the trend is to sell the movie to distributors such as reliance entertainment, yash Raj films, Eros etc. Movies with good star cast sells at good price. Usually, producers don't get share of profit or loss in such scenario.  Suppose distributors pay 35 crore for the movie X. And then invest another 10 crore on its promotion. So the cost is now 45 crores.  Now, these distributors 'distribute' the movie to regional distributors who, in turn, distribute it to theatres. Now the collection is distributed among these 3 tiers.  For a distributor to recover 45 crores, the movie should collect about 80 crores. If it earns anything above this, this will be considered hit. It should also be noted that the movie also earns through satellite rights, music etc.

A hit or a flop are terms assigned to movies on the basis of their box office performance. A movie making money (profit) for it’s makers is designated a hit. A movie that does not make enough money (profit) for it’s makers is designated a flop. On the basis of this criteria, the audience alone makes a movie a hit or a flop. You can make the best movie out there, deserving Academy or Filmfare awards and it will still be qualified as a flop because not enough people saw it. On the other hand, you can make a trashy movie with bad critic reviews and it can still turn out to be a hit because the audience turned out to watch it in troves. Everything else - script, performances, plot, direction - is at the mercy of the audience. As harsh as it sounds, it’s a sad reality of the film business.

Like, say for example, a movie was expected to garner more money, but it is unable to, it might be declared a flop, even though it might have made profit.
